rows: Pairing desired stimulus with aversive UCS
questions.correct_value: Extinction of obsessional anxiety
options: Reciprocal inhibition / counterconditioning
Extinction via habituation
Extinction of obsessional anxiety
Imaginal aversive conditioning
questions.explanation: ERP (Exposure and Response Prevention) works through the extinction of obsessional anxiety by exposing the patient to anxiety-provoking stimuli while preventing the compulsive ritual that would normally reduce the anxiety. Over repeated trials, the obsessional anxiety extinguishes. This is distinct from flooding's extinction via habituation and systematic desensitization's reciprocal inhibition.

rows: Viewing situations in only two categories
"If I'm not perfect, I'm a total failure."
"If I make a mistake, I'll be fired and lose everything."
Assuming you know what others think
Drawing broad conclusions from a single event
"I failed this test; I'll never pass anything."
Focusing on one detail while ignoring the big picture
Dwelling on one critical comment despite many compliments
Magnifying a mistake while minimizing achievements
Attributing external events to oneself without basis
"My friend is upset; it must be something I did."
Using feelings as evidence of truth
"I feel like a fraud, so I must be one."
questions.correct_value: Selective abstraction
options: Overgeneralization
Selective abstraction
Magnification/minimization
Catastrophizing
questions.explanation: Selective abstraction involves focusing on a single detail (e.g., one critical comment) while ignoring the broader context (e.g., many compliments). This is distinct from magnification/minimization, which involves inflating or shrinking the importance of events, and from overgeneralization, which involves drawing sweeping conclusions from a single event.

questions.correct_value: Naturalistic (patient/therapist choice)
options: Random assignment to conditions
Matched assignment based on severity
Naturalistic (patient/therapist choice)
Stratified assignment by diagnosis
questions.explanation: Effectiveness studies use naturalistic assignment, meaning patients and therapists choose treatments as they would in real-world practice, rather than being randomly assigned to conditions. This contrasts with efficacy studies, which use random assignment to maximize internal validity. This distinction is a core differentiator between the two study types on the EPPP.

rows: A child earns a sticker for every 15 minutes without hitting
Reinforce a specific desirable behavior that replaces the problem behavior
Reinforcing hand-raising instead of calling out
Reinforce a behavior that is physically incompatible with the problem behavior
Reinforcing sitting in one's seat (incompatible with wandering)
Reinforce the target behavior only when it occurs at or below a specified rate
Reinforce a talkative student for asking only 3 or fewer questions per class
questions.correct_value: Reinforce the absence of the target behavior for a specified time interval
options: Reinforce a behavior that is physically incompatible with the problem behavior
Reinforce the absence of the target behavior for a specified time interval
Reinforce the target behavior only when it occurs at or below a specified rate
Reinforce a specific desirable behavior that replaces the problem behavior
questions.explanation: DRO (Differential Reinforcement of Other behavior) involves reinforcing the absence of the target behavior for a specified time interval. This is distinct from DRA (reinforcing a specific alternative behavior), DRI (reinforcing a physically incompatible behavior), and DRL (reinforcing low rates of the target behavior). DRO is unique because it does not require any specific replacement behavior — the individual is reinforced simply for not engaging in the problem behavior during the interval.

rows: General population or at-risk groups (before onset)
School-based anti-bullying programs, parenting skills training, Head Start
Individuals showing early signs or at high risk
Depression screening in primary care, crisis intervention hotlines, developmental screening for children
Relapse prevention programs, vocational rehabilitation, supported employment for severe mental illness
questions.correct_value: Reduce incidence
options: Reduce prevalence through early detection
Reduce disability and prevent relapse
Reduce incidence
Reduce severity of existing symptoms
questions.explanation: Primary prevention targets the general population or at-risk groups before the onset of a disorder, and its goal is to reduce incidence (i.e., the number of new cases). This is commonly confused with secondary prevention, which aims to reduce prevalence through early detection, and tertiary prevention, which aims to reduce disability and prevent relapse in those already diagnosed.

rows: Alcohol use disorder -- drinking paired with vomiting
Pairing the target stimulus with mild electric shock
Historically used for various unwanted behaviors
Imagining the target behavior paired with imagined aversive consequences
Clients imagine engaging in the behavior followed by nausea, embarrassment, or other aversive outcomes
questions.correct_value: Pairing the target stimulus with a nausea-inducing agent (e.g., emetine, Antabuse/disulfiram)
options: Imagining the target behavior paired with imagined aversive consequences
Pairing the target stimulus with a nausea-inducing agent (e.g., emetine, Antabuse/disulfiram)
Pairing the target stimulus with mild electric shock
Pairing the target stimulus with an unpleasant taste (e.g., bitter agents)
questions.explanation: Chemical aversion therapy specifically involves pairing the target stimulus (e.g., alcohol) with a pharmacological nausea-inducing agent such as emetine or Antabuse (disulfiram). This distinguishes it from electrical aversion (which uses shock), covert sensitization (which uses imagined aversive consequences), and other potential aversive methods.

questions.section: Four Types of Mental Health Consultation
rows: The consultant assesses the client and provides recommendations to the consultee about the case. Most similar to traditional clinical work. The primary goal is to help the client.
The consultee's difficulty with the case
The consultant evaluates a specific program or organizational problem and provides recommendations.
The focus is on improving the consultee's skills in program development, leadership, or organizational management.
questions.correct_value: The focus is on improving the consultee's ability to handle the case. The problem may stem from lack of knowledge, skill, confidence, or objectivity. Most emphasized by Caplan.
options: The consultant assesses the client and provides recommendations to the consultee about the case. Most similar to traditional clinical work. The primary goal is to help the client.
The focus is on improving the consultee's ability to handle the case. The problem may stem from lack of knowledge, skill, confidence, or objectivity. Most emphasized by Caplan.
The consultant evaluates a specific program or organizational problem and provides recommendations.
The focus is on improving the consultee's skills in program development, leadership, or organizational management.
questions.explanation: Consultee-centered case consultation focuses on improving the consultee's ability to handle the case, with problems potentially stemming from lack of knowledge, skill, confidence, or objectivity. This type was most emphasized by Caplan in his model of mental health consultation, distinguishing it from client-centered case consultation, which focuses directly on the client rather than the consultee's professional development.

rows: Actively confrontational; requires high motivation and specific oedipal focus; provocative interpretation of defenses
Actively challenges defenses; uses "trial therapy" for assessment; aims to unlock unconscious feelings
Focus on the Cyclic Maladaptive Pattern (CMP); 25-30 sessions; emphasizes interpersonal patterns
questions.correct_value: Identifies the Core Conflictual Relationship Theme (CCRT): wish, response from other, response of self
options: Focus on the Cyclic Maladaptive Pattern (CMP); 25-30 sessions; emphasizes interpersonal patterns
Identifies the Core Conflictual Relationship Theme (CCRT): wish, response from other, response of self
Actively challenges defenses; uses "trial therapy" for assessment; aims to unlock unconscious feelings
Actively confrontational; requires high motivation and specific oedipal focus; provocative interpretation of defenses
questions.explanation: Lester Luborsky's Supportive-Expressive Therapy is characterized by identifying the Core Conflictual Relationship Theme (CCRT), which consists of three components: a wish, an expected response from the other, and a response of the self. This is commonly confused with Strupp and Binder's Cyclic Maladaptive Pattern (CMP), but the CCRT is uniquely associated with Luborsky's approach.

rows: Pushing threatening material into the unconscious
Having no memory of a traumatic event
An alcoholic insisting they have no drinking problem
Attributing one's unacceptable feelings to others
"I'm not angry at you -- you're angry at me!"
Redirecting impulses toward a safer target
Yelling at your spouse after a conflict with your boss
Behaving opposite to an unacceptable impulse
Being excessively kind to someone you resent
Creating logical justifications for irrational behavior
Channeling unacceptable impulses into socially acceptable activities
Aggressive urges expressed through competitive sports
Returning to an earlier developmental stage
An adult throwing a tantrum under stress
Being excessively generous after having hostile thoughts
Focusing on abstract/intellectual aspects to avoid emotional content
Discussing the statistics of cancer rather than one's fear of dying
questions.correct_value: Attempting to reverse an unacceptable action or thought
options: Creating logical justifications for irrational behavior
Attempting to reverse an unacceptable action or thought
Behaving opposite to an unacceptable impulse
Focusing on abstract/intellectual aspects to avoid emotional content
questions.explanation: Undoing involves attempting to symbolically reverse or 'undo' an unacceptable action or thought, often through ritualistic or compensatory behavior. This is commonly confused with reaction formation (behaving opposite to an impulse) and rationalization (creating logical justifications), but undoing specifically targets a particular act or thought the person wants to negate.

rows: Questions that cannot be answered with a simple yes/no
"What concerns do you have about your drinking?"
Statements recognizing client strengths and efforts
"It took a lot of courage to come here today."
Statements that mirror or rephrase client speech; simple or complex
"So you're feeling torn between wanting to quit and worrying about losing your social circle."
Collecting and linking several client statements together
"Let me make sure I'm following -- you've mentioned health worries, your wife's concerns, and the expense..."
questions.correct_value: Reflections
options: Summaries
Affirmations
Reflections
Open-ended Questions
questions.explanation: Reflections are statements that mirror or rephrase what the client has said, and can be either simple (repeating) or complex (adding meaning or emphasis). This differs from Summaries, which collect and link multiple client statements together, and from Affirmations, which recognize client strengths rather than rephrase client speech.

rows: Federal early childhood education program for low-income families; aims to promote school readiness and reduce developmental delays
Intensive preschool program for disadvantaged children; long-term follow-up showed reduced crime, higher employment, better educational outcomes
Positive Parenting Program using a public health framework with escalating levels of intervention based on need
questions.correct_value: Drug Abuse Resistance Education delivered in schools; research consistently shows it is not effective in reducing substance use despite widespread adoption
options: Federal early childhood education program for low-income families; aims to promote school readiness and reduce developmental delays
Drug Abuse Resistance Education delivered in schools; research consistently shows it is not effective in reducing substance use despite widespread adoption
Intensive preschool program for disadvantaged children; long-term follow-up showed reduced crime, higher employment, better educational outcomes
Positive Parenting Program using a public health framework with escalating levels of intervention based on need
questions.explanation: DARE (Drug Abuse Resistance Education) is a widely recognized school-based prevention program that, despite its extensive adoption across the United States, has been consistently shown by research to be ineffective in reducing substance use. This is a highly testable fact on the EPPP because it highlights the critical distinction between program popularity/widespread implementation and actual empirical effectiveness.

rows: Complicated bereavement following the death of a significant other
Facilitate mourning process, help establish new relationships and interests
Conflicts with a significant other due to differing expectations
Difficulty coping with life changes (e.g., divorce, retirement, diagnosis)
Mourn the loss of the old role, develop a positive view of the new role, build mastery
Impoverished social networks, chronic loneliness, or poor social skills
Reduce social isolation, enhance social skills, form new relationships
questions.correct_value: Identify the dispute, determine the stage (renegotiation, impasse, dissolution), plan strategies
options: Reduce social isolation, enhance social skills, form new relationships
Identify the dispute, determine the stage (renegotiation, impasse, dissolution), plan strategies
Facilitate mourning process, help establish new relationships and interests
Mourn the loss of the old role, develop a positive view of the new role, build mastery
questions.explanation: In Interpersonal Therapy (IPT), the therapeutic focus for Role Disputes involves identifying the nature of the dispute and determining which stage it is in — renegotiation, impasse, or dissolution — then planning appropriate strategies. This specific three-stage framework (renegotiation, impasse, dissolution) is a highly testable detail that distinguishes Role Disputes from the other three interpersonal problem areas.

rows: "What" skills (observe, describe, participate) and "How" skills (non-judgmentally, one-mindfully, effectively)
Surviving crises without making things worse
ABC PLEASE (Accumulate positives, Build mastery, Cope ahead, treat PhysicaL illness, balance Eating, avoid mood-Altering substances, balance Sleep, get Exercise)
DEAR MAN (Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, Mindful, Appear confident, Negotiate), GIVE, FAST
questions.correct_value: TIPP (Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Paired muscle relaxation), pros/cons, radical acceptance
options: DEAR MAN (Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, Mindful, Appear confident, Negotiate), GIVE, FAST
ABC PLEASE (Accumulate positives, Build mastery, Cope ahead, treat PhysicaL illness, balance Eating, avoid mood-Altering substances, balance Sleep, get Exercise)
TIPP (Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Paired muscle relaxation), pros/cons, radical acceptance
"What" skills (observe, describe, participate) and "How" skills (non-judgmentally, one-mindfully, effectively)
questions.explanation: The Distress Tolerance module in DBT focuses on surviving crises without making things worse. Its key skills include the TIPP acronym (Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Paired muscle relaxation), weighing pros/cons, and radical acceptance. These are distinct from Emotion Regulation skills (ABC PLEASE), Interpersonal Effectiveness skills (DEAR MAN, GIVE, FAST), and Mindfulness skills ('What' and 'How' skills).

rows: 12-step model; sponsor system; emphasis on spiritual growth and powerlessness over alcohol; the most widely known self-help organization
Families of individuals with mental illness
National Alliance on Mental Illness; provides education, advocacy, and family support
Adapted 12-step model for affected family members
Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance; peer-led support and psychoeducation
questions.correct_value: Family members of individuals with alcohol problems
options: Families of individuals with mental illness
Family members of individuals with alcohol problems
Depression and bipolar disorders
Alcohol use disorder
questions.explanation: Al-Anon and Alateen specifically focus on family members of individuals with alcohol problems, using an adapted 12-step model. This is easily confused with NAMI, which focuses on families of individuals with mental illness more broadly, but Al-Anon/Alateen is narrowly focused on the impact of a family member's alcohol use.

rows: Teaching the first step first; the learner completes step 1, then the therapist assists with the rest
When the first step is easiest or most motivating
When the last step is most reinforcing (e.g., eating the food after cooking)
Teaching all steps simultaneously with prompts at each step
When the learner can approximate the entire sequence
questions.correct_value: Teaching the last step first; the therapist completes all steps except the last, which the learner does
options: Teaching the first step first; the learner completes step 1, then the therapist assists with the rest
Teaching the last step first; the therapist completes all steps except the last, which the learner does
Teaching all steps simultaneously with prompts at each step
Teaching the middle steps first; the therapist models the first and last steps while the learner practices the intermediate steps
questions.explanation: Backward chaining involves teaching the last step first, with the therapist completing all preceding steps and the learner performing only the final step. This is easily confused with forward chaining (which starts with the first step) and total task presentation (which teaches all steps at once). The key distinguishing feature is that backward chaining leverages the natural reinforcement that occurs at the end of a behavior chain.

rows: Teaching skills and information (e.g., anger management, social skills)
Mutual aid among people with shared concerns (e.g., AA, grief support)
May be peer-led; emphasis on shared experience
Applying CBT techniques in a group format
Exploring unconscious processes and transference within the group
questions.correct_value: Unstructured; interactions among members are the primary vehicle for change
options: Semi-structured; therapist interprets group dynamics
Unstructured; interactions among members are the primary vehicle for change
Structured; skills-based with homework
Structured curriculum, leader-directed
questions.explanation: Process/interpersonal groups, based on Yalom's model, are characteristically unstructured because the here-and-now interactions among group members serve as the primary vehicle for therapeutic change. This distinguishes them from psychodynamic groups (semi-structured with therapist interpretation), CBT groups (structured with homework), and psychoeducational groups (structured, leader-directed curriculum).

questions.correct_value: Top-down (research dictates practice)
options: Integrative (research + expertise + patient)
Bottom-up (practice informs research)
Top-down (research dictates practice)
Collaborative (clinician-patient driven)
questions.explanation: ESTs use a top-down approach where research dictates practice, meaning that treatments are identified through controlled research (primarily RCTs) and then applied in clinical settings. This contrasts with EBP's integrative approach, which combines research evidence with clinical expertise and patient factors.

questions.correct_value: 12-16 sessions
options: 1-4 sessions (often adjunctive)
12-16 sessions
5-8 sessions
16-20 sessions
questions.explanation: Interpersonal Therapy (IPT), developed by Klerman and Weissman, is a structured, time-limited therapy that typically spans 12-16 sessions. This distinguishes it from SFBT (5-8 sessions) and MI (1-4 sessions), making IPT the longest of the three brief therapy approaches listed.

rows: Client variables, life events, social support, fortuitous events -- factors outside therapy
Empathy, warmth, acceptance, therapeutic alliance -- the relationship itself
The client's hope and expectation that therapy will help
Factors unique to particular therapies (e.g., systematic desensitization, cognitive restructuring)
questions.explanation: In Lambert's Outcome Variance Model, the therapeutic relationship (including empathy, warmth, acceptance, and therapeutic alliance) accounts for approximately 30% of therapy outcome variance. This is the second largest contributor after extratherapeutic factors (~40%), and is commonly tested because it is frequently confused with the ~15% contributions of expectancy/placebo effects and specific techniques.

rows: The therapist accommodates to the family's style to build rapport; entering the family system before attempting to change it
Asking family members to interact with each other in session rather than talking to the therapist, so the therapist can observe actual patterns
Strengthening or loosening boundaries between subsystems (e.g., having enmeshed parent-child dyad sit farther apart)
Deliberately siding with one family member to shift the power structure and disrupt a dysfunctional hierarchy
Actively reorganizing the family's transactional patterns through directives, seating changes, and task assignments
questions.correct_value: Unbalancing
options: Joining
Restructuring
Unbalancing
Enactment
questions.explanation: Unbalancing is the structural technique in which the therapist deliberately sides with one family member to shift the power structure and disrupt a dysfunctional hierarchy. This is distinct from 'joining' (building rapport by accommodating to the family), 'restructuring' (broadly reorganizing transactional patterns), and 'enactment' (having family members interact in session for observation).

rows: Realizing "I am not alone" -- others share similar struggles
Psychoeducation and advice from therapist and members
Helping others enhances one's own self-esteem and sense of purpose
The group re-creates family dynamics, allowing corrective emotional experiences
Learning social skills through group interaction
Modeling -- observing and imitating adaptive behaviors of others
Gaining insight into one's interpersonal impact through feedback
The sense of belonging and acceptance; the group analog of the therapeutic alliance
Emotional release and expression of feelings in a safe context
Confronting fundamental issues of existence (responsibility, mortality, meaning)
questions.correct_value: Corrective recapitulation of the primary family group
options: Interpersonal learning
Corrective recapitulation of the primary family group
Group cohesiveness
Development of socializing techniques
questions.explanation: Yalom's factor #5, 'Corrective recapitulation of the primary family group,' specifically refers to how the therapy group re-creates early family dynamics, giving members the opportunity to work through unresolved family-of-origin issues via corrective emotional experiences. This is distinct from 'Interpersonal learning' (gaining insight through feedback), 'Group cohesiveness' (sense of belonging), and 'Development of socializing techniques' (learning social skills).
